after: Sugarcane was the backbone of HawaiÊ»i Island's economy for more than a century. In the mid-twentieth century, sugar plantations began to downsize and in 1996, the last plantation closed.

Most of HawaiÊ»i Island's economy is based on tourism, centered primarily in resort areas on the western coast of the island in the North Kona and South Kohala districts. More recently, HawaiÊ»i Island has become a focus for sustainable tourism.
